This week's best reads from the front lines of the fight for civil liberties.
 
SCHOOL-TO-PRISON PIPELINE

This County Criminalized Students for Bad Grades – Until Now

Since 2001, the Riverside County probation department has been needlessly funneling young people struggling with grades, behavior, trauma, and mental health issues into the criminal justice system – instead of providing them the support they need. This week, we filed a landmark settlement with the federal district court that will end the relationship between the probation department and school districts in Riverside, California. The settlement will ensure that educational outcomes for students improve and that this county becomes a national model for juvenile justice. Read more →

By Sarah Hinger and Sylvia Torres-Guill√©n
July 25, 2019

 
AT LIBERTY PODCAST

The Constitution Gets the Broadway Treatment

Heidi Schreck, the playwright and star of Broadway's "What the Constitution Means to Me," joins us this week in the studio. The play, which was nominated for two Tonys and was a Pulitzer finalist, was inspired by Schreck's experience as a teenager competing in debates about the Constitution at American Legion halls across the country. As an adult, she revisits her personal connection to the document to see how her relationship to it, and American democracy on the whole, hold up in new light. Listen here →

By ACLU Staff
July 25, 2019

 
VICTORY FOR TRANS RIGHTS

Trans People Led the Fight Against HB2 in North Carolina – and We're Winning

A federal court ordered that the discriminatory bathroom bills passed by the state legislature in North Carolina cannot be used to bar transgender people from restrooms that match their gender. This victory comes three years after the ACLU and Lambda Legal filed a lawsuit to stop these measures. The fight, however, is far from over: Local protections for LGBTQ people are still banned under state law, and many members of the community continue to face violence, harassment, and discrimination. Read more →

By Joaqu√≠n Carca√±o
July 24, 2019

 
ALL EYES ON MAUNAKEA

Hawaiians are Taking to the Streets and Exercising their First Amendment Rights

This week marks the second week of protests on mountain Maunakea over the construction of the Thirty Meter Telescope. Our concern for the free speech rights of everyone and the cultural access rights of Native Hawaiians drove us to get involved. We sent over teams of legal observers to make sure that protectors were allowed to exercise their right to free speech and ensure there was no law enforcement misconduct. Read more →

By Kathleen Wong and Rae Shih
July 25, 2019

 
DEFENDING TOFURKY

Arkansas Wants to Make Sure You Know 'Almonds Don't Lactate'

An Arkansas law makes it illegal for companies to use words like "meat," "roast," and "sausage" to describe products that are not made from animals. A lawmaker has admitted that the law is designed to "protect the agricultural producers in the state." Not only does this law clearly violate the First Amendment, but it allows the state government to defend the interests of one industry over the rights of the consumer. We filed a suit challenging the law earlier this week on behalf of Tofurky. Read more →

By Brian Hauss
July 22, 2019

 
TAXATION WITHOUT REPRESENTATION

Washington, D.C. Residents Deserve the Full Benefits of Citizenship

Despite the fact that D.C. residents pay more in taxes per capita than any other state, they have no representation in Congress. As a "federal district," D.C. lacks complete autonomy over its laws and budget, so members of Congress, none of whom were elected by D.C. voters, can strike down laws they don't like. Unless Washington D.C. is granted statehood, this oppression will continue. Read more →

By Monica Hopkins
July 19, 2019

 
A TEXAS-SIZED OBSESSION

Texas Sentenced Crystal Mason to Five Years in Prison for Trying to Vote

Crystal Mason cast a provisional ballot in the 2016 election. At the time, however, she was on "federal supervised release," and didn't realize she was ineligible to vote during that period. Now, Texas wants to send her to prison for five years for this honest mistake. In some ways, Crystal's story is uniquely extreme. In other ways, it's the predictable outcome of an obsession with supposed rampant voter fraud shared by Texas and much of the country. Read more →

By Amrit Cheng
 
BACKDOOR TO YOUR DATA

The 'Ghost User' Ploy to Break Encryption: A Four-Part Series

In this series, ACLU Senior Technology Fellow and security expert Jon Callas breaks down the dangers in a new proposal to circumvent encryption. A recent essay by technical leaders of Britain's GCHQ proposes a law that would require software companies to enable the secret addition of an extra user – the government – to spy on an otherwise securely encrypted conversation, thereby destroying the confidentiality and privacy encrypted communications provide us. The proposal is dangerous, and will not work. Read more →

By Jon Callas
July 16, 2019
